title: How to Make a Period Kit

steps.headline: Get a small bag or purse.
steps.description: You need something to serve as your kit! But make sure it is big enough to hold pads and, if you use them, tampons.

steps.headline: Get some sanitary products.
steps.description: Usually, your first period is very light and just spotting, so pantyliners are perfect. For a heavier flow, you'll want pads or tampons. Alternatives are menstrual/soft cups or reusable, cloth pads. You'll need about 3 liners and 3 pads or tampons to last you through a work or school day. Be sure to change your pad every 4-6 hours and your tampon every 6-8 hours.

steps.headline: Add pain medications.
steps.description: There's a high possibility you'll get period cramps, which aren't pleasant. Ibuprofen works well to reduce the pain; if you're really hurting badly, you can take up to four at a time as long as you don't exceed the daily limit listed on the label.

steps.headline: Add a small calendar and pen.
steps.description: If you're unsure of when exactly your period is, write down the date every month until you find your pattern.

steps.headline: Include extra underwear.
steps.description: Extra underwear can be helpful, especially if you stain your current pair of undies. In this case, you'll want a Ziploc bag to hold your stained panties.

steps.headline: If you have space in your bag, you can add in an extra pair of pants as well, in case your period is exceptionally heavy and your pad/tampon leaks.
steps.description: (If this is a regular problem, consider wearing both a pad and a tampon, changing your product to something that doesn't leak, or taking birth control for lighter periods.) Be aware of the hormonal changes that occur with the consumption of birth control pills. Only use it if you know the pros and cons.

steps.headline: Get some hand sanitizer.
steps.description: It always helps when the bathroom's out of soap!

steps.headline: It can help to include some feminine wipes.
steps.description: Make sure that they are biodegradable and not scented.

steps.headline: Add in a plastic baggy to hold soiled underwear and/or pants.
steps.description: A plastic baggy can also be useful if there is not a place to dispose of a used tampon or pad (on a hike, at the beach, etc.)

steps.headline: Also put in a dollar's worth of quarters, in case you forget to refill your kit and need to get some from a machine.
Put in some chocolate (optional), especially dark chocolate - make sure it's in a Ziploc bag as well.
steps.description: The chemicals in chocolate can help with your cramps and satisfy that craving you're probably having.

tyn: Pants, shorts, skirt, or any other comfortable extra clothing
